title: Kinetic energy
text:
In <a href="physics">physics</a>, the kinetic energy of an object is the <a href="energy">energy</a> that it possesses due to its <a href="motion%20%28physics%29">motion</a>.
It is defined as the <a href="work%20%28physics%29">work</a> needed to accelerate a body of a given mass from rest to its stated <a href="velocity">velocity</a>. Having gained this energy during its <a href="acceleration">acceleration</a>, the body maintains this kinetic energy unless its speed changes. The same amount of work is done by the body when decelerating from its current speed to a state of rest. Formally, a kinetic energy is any term in a system's <a href="Lagrangian%20mechanics">Lagrangian</a> which includes a <a href="Partial%20derivative">derivative</a> with respect to <a href="Time">time</a>. 
In <a href="classical%20mechanics">classical mechanics</a>, the kinetic energy of a non-rotating object of <a href="mass">mass</a> "m" traveling at a <a href="speed">speed</a> "v" is formula_1. In <a href="Special%20relativity">relativistic mechanics</a>, this is a good approximation only when "v" is much less than the <a href="speed%20of%20light">speed of light</a>.
The <a href="International%20System%20of%20Units">standard unit</a> of kinetic energy is the <a href="joule">joule</a>, while the <a href="English%20Engineering%20Units">English unit</a> of kinetic energy is the <a href="foot-pound">foot-pound</a>.
History and etymology.
The adjective "kinetic" has its roots in the <a href="Ancient%20Greek">Greek</a> word κίνησις "kinesis", meaning "motion". The dichotomy between kinetic energy and <a href="potential%20energy">potential energy</a> can be traced back to <a href="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>'s concepts of <a href="actuality%20and%20potentiality">actuality and potentiality</a>. 
The principle in <a href="classical%20mechanics">classical mechanics</a> that "E" ∝ "mv"2 was first developed by <a href="Gottfried%20Leibniz">Gottfried Leibniz</a> and <a href="Johann%20Bernoulli">Johann Bernoulli</a>, who described kinetic energy as the "living force", "<a href="vis%20viva">vis viva</a>". <a href="Willem%20%27s%20Gravesande">Willem 's Gravesande</a> of the Netherlands provided experimental evidence of this relationship. By dropping weights from different heights into a block of clay, <a href="Willem%20%27s%20Gravesande">Willem 's Gravesande</a> determined that their penetration depth was proportional to the square of their impact speed. <a href="%C3%89milie%20du%20Ch%C3%A2telet">Émilie du Châtelet</a> recognized the implications of the experiment and published an explanation.
The terms "kinetic energy" and "work" in their present scientific meanings date back to the mid-19th century. Early understandings of these ideas can be attributed to <a href="Gaspard-Gustave%20Coriolis">Gaspard-Gustave Coriolis</a>, who in 1829 published the paper titled "Du Calcul de l'Effet des Machines" outlining the mathematics of kinetic energy. <a href="William%20Thomson%2C%201st%20Baron%20Kelvin">William Thomson</a>, later Lord Kelvin, is given the credit for coining the term "kinetic energy" c. 1849–1851. <a href="Macquorn%20Rankine">Rankine</a>, who had introduced the term "potential energy" in 1853, and the phrase "actual energy" to complement it, later cites <a href="William%20Thomson%2C%201st%20Baron%20Kelvin">William Thomson</a> and <a href="Peter%20Tait%20%28physicist%29">Peter Tait</a> as substituting the word "kinetic" for "actual".
Overview.
<a href="Energy">Energy</a> occurs in many forms, including <a href="chemical%20energy">chemical energy</a>, <a href="thermal%20energy">thermal energy</a>, <a href="electromagnetic%20radiation">electromagnetic radiation</a>, <a href="gravitational%20energy">gravitational energy</a>, <a href="electric%20energy">electric energy</a>, <a href="elastic%20energy">elastic energy</a>, <a href="nuclear%20binding%20energy">nuclear energy</a>, and <a href="rest%20energy">rest energy</a>. These can be categorized in two main classes: <a href="potential%20energy">potential energy</a> and kinetic energy. Kinetic energy is the movement energy of an object. Kinetic energy can be transferred between objects and transformed into other kinds of energy.
Kinetic energy may be best understood by examples that demonstrate how it is transformed to and from other forms of energy. For example, a <a href="cyclist">cyclist</a> uses <a href="food%20energy">chemical energy provided by food</a> to accelerate a <a href="bicycle">bicycle</a> to a chosen speed. On a level surface, this speed can be maintained without further work, except to overcome <a href="drag%20%28physics%29">air resistance</a> and <a href="friction">friction</a>. The chemical energy has been converted into kinetic energy, the energy of motion, but the process is not completely efficient and produces heat within the cyclist.
The kinetic energy in the moving cyclist and the bicycle can be converted to other forms. For example, the cyclist could encounter a hill just high enough to coast up, so that the bicycle comes to a complete halt at the top. The kinetic energy has now largely been converted to gravitational potential energy that can be released by freewheeling down the other side of the hill. Since the bicycle lost some of its energy to friction, it never regains all of its speed without additional pedaling. The energy is not destroyed; it has only been converted to another form by friction. Alternatively, the cyclist could connect a <a href="Bottle%20dynamo">dynamo</a> to one of the wheels and generate some electrical energy on the descent. The bicycle would be traveling slower at the bottom of the hill than without the generator because some of the energy has been diverted into electrical energy. Another possibility would be for the cyclist to apply the brakes, in which case the kinetic energy would be dissipated through friction as <a href="heat">heat</a>.
Like any physical quantity that is a function of velocity, the kinetic energy of an object depends on the relationship between the object and the observer's <a href="frame%20of%20reference">frame of reference</a>. Thus, the kinetic energy of an object is not <a href="Galilean%20invariance">invariant</a>.
<a href="Spacecraft">Spacecraft</a> use chemical energy to launch and gain considerable kinetic energy to reach <a href="orbital%20speed">orbital velocity</a>. In an entirely circular orbit, this kinetic energy remains constant because there is almost no friction in near-earth space. However, it becomes apparent at re-entry when some of the kinetic energy is converted to heat. If the orbit is <a href="elliptic%20orbit">elliptical</a> or <a href="hyperbolic%20trajectory">hyperbolic</a>, then throughout the orbit kinetic and <a href="potential%20energy">potential energy</a> are exchanged; kinetic energy is greatest and potential energy lowest at closest approach to the earth or other massive body, while potential energy is greatest and kinetic energy the lowest at maximum distance. Disregarding loss or gain however, the sum of the kinetic and potential energy remains constant.
Kinetic energy can be passed from one object to another. In the game of <a href="billiards">billiards</a>, the player imposes kinetic energy on the cue ball by striking it with the cue stick. If the cue ball collides with another ball, it slows down dramatically, and the ball it hit accelerates its speed as the kinetic energy is passed on to it. <a href="Collisions">Collisions</a> in billiards are effectively <a href="elastic%20collision">elastic collision</a>s, in which kinetic energy is preserved. In <a href="inelastic%20collision">inelastic collision</a>s, kinetic energy is dissipated in various forms of energy, such as heat, sound and binding energy (breaking bound structures).
<a href="Flywheel">Flywheel</a>s have been developed as a method of <a href="flywheel%20energy%20storage">energy storage</a>. This illustrates that kinetic energy is also stored in rotational motion.
Several mathematical descriptions of kinetic energy exist that describe it in the appropriate physical situation. For objects and processes in common human experience, the formula ½mv² given by <a href="Newtonian%20mechanics">Newtonian (classical) mechanics</a> is suitable. However, if the speed of the object is comparable to the speed of light, <a href="special%20relativity">relativistic effects</a> become significant and the relativistic formula is used. If the object is on the atomic or <a href="sub-atomic%20scale">sub-atomic scale</a>, <a href="quantum%20mechanical">quantum mechanical</a> effects are significant, and a quantum mechanical model must be employed.
Newtonian kinetic energy.
Kinetic energy of rigid bodies.
In <a href="classical%20mechanics">classical mechanics</a>, the kinetic energy of a "point object" (an object so small that its mass can be assumed to exist at one point), or a non-rotating <a href="rigid%20body">rigid body</a> depends on the <a href="mass">mass</a> of the body as well as its <a href="speed">speed</a>. The kinetic energy is equal to 1/2 the <a href="Multiplication">product</a> of the mass and the square of the speed. In formula form:

When a person throws a ball, the person does <a href="work%20%28physics%29">work</a> on it to give it speed as it leaves the hand. The moving ball can then hit something and push it, doing work on what it hits. The kinetic energy of a moving object is equal to the work required to bring it from rest to that speed, or the work the object can do while being brought to rest: net force × displacement = kinetic energy, i.e.,
Since the kinetic energy increases with the square of the speed, an object doubling its speed has four times as much kinetic energy. For example, a car traveling twice as fast as another requires four times as much distance to stop, assuming a constant braking force. As a consequence of this quadrupling, it takes four times the work to double the speed.

The kinetic energy of any entity depends on the reference frame in which it is measured. However, the total energy of an isolated system, i.e. one in which energy can neither enter nor leave, does not change over time in the reference frame in which it is measured. Thus, the chemical energy converted to kinetic energy by a rocket engine is divided differently between the rocket ship and its exhaust stream depending upon the chosen reference frame. This is called the <a href="Oberth%20effect">Oberth effect</a>. But the total energy of the system, including kinetic energy, fuel chemical energy, heat, etc., is conserved over time, regardless of the choice of reference frame. Different observers moving with different reference frames would however disagree on the value of this conserved energy.
The kinetic energy of such systems depends on the choice of reference frame: the reference frame that gives the minimum value of that energy is the <a href="center%20of%20momentum">center of momentum</a> frame, i.e. the reference frame in which the total momentum of the system is zero. This minimum kinetic energy contributes to the <a href="invariant%20mass">invariant mass</a> of the system as a whole.

Kinetic energy of systems.
A system of bodies may have internal kinetic energy due to the relative motion of the bodies in the system. For example, in the <a href="Solar%20System">Solar System</a> the planets and planetoids are orbiting the Sun. In a tank of gas, the molecules are moving in all directions. The kinetic energy of the system is the sum of the kinetic energies of the bodies it contains.
A macroscopic body that is stationary (i.e. a reference frame has been chosen to correspond to the body's <a href="center%20of%20momentum">center of momentum</a>) may have various kinds of <a href="internal%20energy">internal energy</a> at the molecular or atomic level, which may be regarded as kinetic energy, due to molecular translation, rotation, and vibration, electron translation and spin, and nuclear spin. These all contribute to the body's mass, as provided by the special theory of relativity. When discussing movements of a macroscopic body, the kinetic energy referred to is usually that of the macroscopic movement only. However, all internal energies of all types contribute to a body's mass, inertia, and total energy.

Frame of reference.
The speed, and thus the kinetic energy of a single object is frame-dependent (relative): it can take any non-negative value, by choosing a suitable <a href="inertial%20frame%20of%20reference">inertial frame of reference</a>. For example, a bullet passing an observer has kinetic energy in the reference frame of this observer. The same bullet is stationary to an observer moving with the same velocity as the bullet, and so has zero kinetic energy. By contrast, the total kinetic energy of a system of objects cannot be reduced to zero by a suitable choice of the inertial reference frame, unless all the objects have the same velocity. In any other case, the total kinetic energy has a non-zero minimum, as no inertial reference frame can be chosen in which all the objects are stationary. This minimum kinetic energy contributes to the system's <a href="invariant%20mass">invariant mass</a>, which is independent of the reference frame.
The total kinetic energy of a system depends on the <a href="inertial%20frame%20of%20reference">inertial frame of reference</a>: it is the sum of the total kinetic energy in a <a href="center%20of%20momentum%20frame">center of momentum frame</a> and the kinetic energy the total mass would have if it were concentrated in the <a href="center%20of%20mass">center of mass</a>.
